citations.narrative:
The licensee conducted an animal encounter with a gibbon as part of her regulated business. However, Group 6
nonhuman primates, gibbons, are not listed or approved on the licensee’s license. The licensee must immediately cease
any regulated activities with gibbons and reapply for a new license if regulated activity will be conducted in the future with
the gibbons or any Group 6 nonhuman primates.
Documented 24 SEPT 2025 and to be corrected by 24 SEPT 2025

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the licensee was unable to provide a completed written Program of Veterinary Care. The only
portion that was completed and available for inspection was the page with the attending veterinarian’s signature. A written
program of veterinary care is required to ensure the animals are receiving routine preventive medical care, authorized
treatments for specific conditions, and euthanasia for animals maintained by the facility. Without a written program of
veterinary care, animals may not be receiving adequate veterinary care. The facility must ensure that a written program of
veterinary care is in place for each regulated species and must be able to provide this document during inspection.
Documented on 24 SEPT 2025 and to be corrected by 08 OCT 2025

The licensee stated that a customer paid for an animal encounter with a gibbon at the facility and the customer was bitten.
The gibbon was not leashed and placed into the customer’s lap and was bitten on her chest. Licensee stated that this
occurred around 3 months ago and the sheriff was notified immediately. The gibbon was quarantined for 10 days. During
public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient safeguards as to assure the safety of animals and the public.
Documented on 24 SEPT 2025 and to be corrected by 24 SEPT 2025

In the outdoor capuchin enclosure, there was cleaning equipment (metal rake with scooper) left inside the enclosure.
Cleaning equipment is also hung outside of the enclosure where the animal can easily access the equipment. Some of
the equipment has sharp points and the animal could injure itself. Primary enclosures must be maintained so that they
have no sharp points or edges and should protect the nonhuman primate from injury. The facility must store cleaning
equipment away from the animal.
Documented on 24 SEPT 2025 and to be corrected by 24 SEPT 2025.

In the indoor housing facility, the primary enclosure for the armadillos had many flies inside the enclosure and around
their food bowl. There were also cockroaches, alive and dead, present inside the housing facility for the armadillos. The
presence of pests can lead to health hazards for the animals. A safe and effective program for the control of pests must
be established and maintained.
Documented on 24 SEPT 2025 and to be corrected by 25 OCTOBER 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Ronald Richardson, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.1(b)(2)(ii) 
   
Requirements and application 
The licensee conducted an animal encounter with a gibbon as part of her regulated business. However, Group 6 
nonhuman primates, gibbons, are not listed or approved on the licensee’s license. The licensee must immediately cease 
any regulated activities with gibbons and reapply for a new license if regulated activity will be conducted in the future with 
the gibbons or any Group 6 nonhuman primates.  
 
Documented 24 SEPT 2025 and to be corrected by 24 SEPT 2025 
2.40 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
At the time of inspection, the licensee was unable to provide a completed written Program of Veterinary Care. The only 
portion that was completed and available for inspection was the page with the attending veterinarian’s signature. A written 
program of veterinary care is required to ensure the animals are receiving routine preventive medical care, authorized 
treatments for specific conditions, and euthanasia for animals maintained by the facility. Without a written program of 
veterinary care, animals may not be receiving adequate veterinary care. The facility must ensure that a written program of 
veterinary care is in place for each regulated species and must be able to provide this document during inspection.  
 
Documented on 24 SEPT 2025 and to be corrected by 08 OCT 2025 
2.131(c)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
The licensee stated that a customer paid for an animal encounter with a gibbon at the facility and the customer was bitten. 
The gibbon was not leashed and placed into the customer’s lap and was bitten on her chest. Licensee stated that this 
occurred around 3 months ago and the sheriff was notified immediately. The gibbon was quarantined for 10 days. During 
public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with 
sufficient safeguards as to assure the safety of animals and the public.  
 
Documented on 24 SEPT 2025 and to be corrected by 24 SEPT 2025

3.80(a)(2) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
In the outdoor capuchin enclosure, there was cleaning equipment (metal rake with scooper) left inside the enclosure. 
Cleaning equipment is also hung outside of the enclosure where the animal can easily access the equipment. Some of 
the equipment has sharp points and the animal could injure itself. Primary enclosures must be maintained so that they 
have no sharp points or edges and should protect the nonhuman primate from injury. The facility must store cleaning 
equipment away from the animal.  
 
Documented on 24 SEPT 2025 and to be corrected by 24 SEPT 2025. 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
In the indoor housing facility, the primary enclosure for the armadillos had many flies inside the enclosure and around 
their food bowl. There were also cockroaches, alive and dead, present inside the housing facility for the armadillos. The 
presence of pests can lead to health hazards for the animals. A safe and effective program for the control of pests must 
be established and maintained.  
 
Documented on 24 SEPT 2025 and to be corrected by 25 OCTOBER 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Ronald Richardson, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
